Our recommendations are very clear on these issues; that, first of all, we feel that testing should always be voluntary.
Information about an HIV test should always be provided in a language that the person can understand, so they know that an HIV test is being offered.
They should always have the opportunity to ask questions about the test, and given an opportunity to decline testing if they choose not to have it.
So this information should be provided.
People should know they're going to be tested, and that is very important that people have an opportunity to learn their test and the information is transmitted to them.
And especially for those people who are identified as HIV/AIDS-positive, the first test would usually be a preliminary test.

Well, I have two concerns that I have heard from critics and in the community.
The first is that the use of opt-out tests often deteriorate into testing without a patient's knowledge or consent.
And that violates the most basic rights of patients: the right to make an informed, voluntary decision about whether or not to undergo a test or any kind of treatment.
We had this discussion with Terry Schiavo a couple of ago.
A second concern is that testing is not treatment and there's no guarantee that anyone with a positive test will get treatment here.
I think we all share the goal of trying to get people into treatment to help them live longer and better lives, but this is only a recommendation for testing.

It can't create the link to treatment, and so the only guaranteed consequence of more testing is simply that more people who test positive will be reported to their health department and ultimately to the CDC.
